repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem:
On Windows, `vim.ui.open("C:\\")` returned successfully but did not show an Explorer window.

Solution:
For has('win32') branch, delegate rundll32 to cmd /c start:
 `cmd /c start explorer.exe {path}` for filesystem paths.
 `cmd /c start "" {path}` for URLs and other URIs.
Also removes the branch related to the now depreciated rundll32.

fix #36293

comment_data.body:
function name is not really saying what this actually does (a "path" could be a file). based on the logic, can you confirm this is a correct docstring, and if so, update the docstring + function name:


~~Checks if `p` is a Windows drive ("C:") or a directory.~~
~~local function is_win_drive_or_dir(p)~~

Oh, from the PR description it looks like you want to check that the paths is "not a URI".
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -118,6 +118,11 @@ function M.input(opts, on_confirm)
   end
 end
 
+local function is_windows_path(p)

comment_data.body:
I think we could avoid this function if we changed this line https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/4337d71a882a32eb255447990004fe012149580e/runtime/lua/vim/ui.lua#L162 

to : 

    local is_uri = path:match('%w%w+:')

The old (current) `is_uri` considers drive-letter paths to be URIs, which is wrong.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -118,6 +118,11 @@ function M.input(opts, on_confirm)
   end
 end
 
+local function is_windows_path(p)

comment_data.body:
~~The function is to identify Windows filesystem paths that should be opened in Explorer, fitting the docstrong and revised function name you provided, I'll make updates and will perform a rebase.~~
*Great catch*
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -118,6 +118,11 @@ function M.input(opts, on_confirm)
   end
 end
 
+local function is_windows_path(p)

comment_data.body: Would checking `not is_uri` also work, if the change I [suggested](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/36756#discussion_r2573400273) above is made?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -118,6 +118,11 @@ function M.input(opts, on_confirm)
   end
 end
 
+local function is_windows_path(p)

comment_data.body: Yes that work, sorry, I did not see your suggestion earlier.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -118,6 +118,11 @@ function M.input(opts, on_confirm)
   end
 end
 
+local function is_windows_path(p)

comment_regular_data.body:
Interesting, thanks. I just merged https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/36731 since it was at least part of the change here, so this needs a rebase.

Does this close https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/36293 ? cc @ymich9963 

Can you confirm that this PR works with `vim.ui.open('https://devdocs.io/#q=lua%20lua_call')` as described in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/23401#issuecomment-1641015704

> Interesting, thanks. I just merged #36731 since it was at least part of the change here, so this needs a rebase.
> 
> Does this close #36293 ? cc @ymich9963
> 
> Can you confirm that this PR works with `vim.ui.open('https://devdocs.io/#q=lua%20lua_call')` as described in [#23401 (comment)](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/23401#issuecomment-1641015704)

Re the URL case from #23401:
:lua vim.ui.open('https://devdocs.io/#q=lua%20lua_call') opens correctly in the default browser for me with this PR applied.

Yes, it closes ticket #36293

I'm confused. Why do we need to check if it's a URI? 

```
cmd.exe /c start "" "C:/Program Files"
cmd.exe /c start "" "file:///C:/Program Files"
```
both of these work in Command Prompt.

Also it does not seem to close https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/36293 for me. Instead of hiding `explorer.exe` it opens it in the Documents folder...which is definitely interesting...

Edit: The command 
```
cmd.exe /c start explorer.exe "C:/Program Files"
```
opens the Documents folder for me.

> opens the Documents folder for me.

Is `nvim` started from your `C:` drive or another drive like `D:` ?

@SahKh can you please check if current master (which uses `cmd /c start` always) works for all cases or if `explorer` is actually required for URLS?

Note that `cmd /c start` was used before https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/23401 , and the rationale for using `explorer` and/or `rundll32` is here: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/23401#issuecomment-1620901417 

So we are going in circles, and need to say exactly which cases work / don't work for which variants. In particular, check which drive `nvim` is installed to and considers its "current drive" vs the drive path you try to open with `vim.ui.open`.

> Is `nvim` started from your `C:` drive or another drive like `D:` ?

`C:` drive. Using the current master implementation I can still open my `G:` drive for example.

> Note that `cmd /c start` was used before #23401 , and the rationale for using `explorer` and/or `rundll32` is here: [#23401 (comment)](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/23401#issuecomment-1620901417)

The implementation there for `start`,

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/23401/files#diff-728d3ae352b52f16b51a57055a3b20efc4e992efacbf1c34426dfccbba30037cL578

 is wrong or at least didn't work for me. See my discussion post https://github.com/neovim/neovim/discussions/36700.

> The implementation there for `start`,
> 
> https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/23401/files#diff-728d3ae352b52f16b51a57055a3b20efc4e992efacbf1c34426dfccbba30037cL578
> 
> is wrong

Ah yes, the `'""'` arg is different. Subtle but important.

Ok then perhaps we are making progress instead of going in circles :)

> > The implementation there for `start`,
> > https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/23401/files#diff-728d3ae352b52f16b51a57055a3b20efc4e992efacbf1c34426dfccbba30037cL578
> > is wrong
> 
> Ah yes, the `'""'` arg is different. Subtle but important.
> 
> Ok then perhaps we are making progress instead of going in circles :)

I believe this can be closed in favor of the change that's already been merged. Initially, `master` only worked for URLs but not filesystem paths on my machine. I've tested the `master` implementation on two other machines and got it working for all cases.

On my local machine, it turns out there were multiple invisible Explorer instances from previous testing. After restarting the Explorer service, the `master` implementation started working for all cases as well.

title: fix(ui.open): open Windows paths in Explorer (#36293)
